output.conclusion: This course provides a foundational understanding of signals and systems, equipping you with the necessary tools to analyze and manipulate signals in various applications.
output.courseTitle: Signals and Systems: A Beginner's Guide
output.introduction: Welcome to Signals and Systems! This course will introduce you to the fundamental concepts of signals and systems, providing a solid foundation for further study in areas like signal processing, communication, and control systems. We'll cover basic signal types, system properties, and fundamental analysis techniques.

chapters.description: What are signals? Examples of real-world signals (audio, video, sensor data). Basic signal classifications: continuous-time vs. discrete-time, periodic vs. aperiodic, energy vs. power signals.
Time shifting, time scaling, and amplitude scaling of signals. Examples and graphical representations of these operations.
Unit impulse function (delta function), unit step function, ramp function, and exponential signals. Their mathematical definitions and graphical representations.
What are systems? Examples of real-world systems (amplifiers, filters, control systems). Block diagram representation of systems.
Linearity, time-invariance, causality, and stability. Understanding these properties and their implications.
Introduction to LTI systems. Why LTI systems are important and widely used.
Understanding the convolution integral for continuous-time LTI systems. Graphical interpretation of convolution.
Understanding the convolution sum for discrete-time LTI systems. Examples of calculating the convolution sum.
Commutativity, associativity, distributivity, and identity element properties of convolution.
Representing periodic signals as a sum of sinusoids. Introduction to Fourier series coefficients.
Formulas for calculating Fourier series coefficients for different types of periodic signals.
Linearity, time shifting, time scaling, and differentiation properties of Fourier series.
Extending Fourier series to aperiodic signals. Definition of the Fourier transform.
Linearity, time shifting, time scaling, duality, and convolution properties of the Fourier transform.
Fourier transforms of common signals like the impulse function, step function, and exponential signals.
Definition of the Laplace transform and its region of convergence (ROC).
Linearity, time shifting, time scaling, differentiation, and integration properties of the Laplace transform.
Using the Laplace transform to solve linear differential equations with initial conditions.
